body_text.text: In the Journal of Thoracic Oncology, Sufang Tian and colleagues reported one of the patients died of COVID-19 after lung lobectomy for adenocarcinoma 1 We took the following measures to exclude of them. First, the patients to be admitted to the hospital were asked about their medical history in detail, including the contact history of COVID-19 and whether they had fever, cough, diarrhea, sore throat or other symptoms in the past 2 weeks. After taking the medical history, the patient signed a form promising to disclose their medical history without any concealment; otherwise, the patient will bear legal responsibility. Second, chest CT examination, routine blood parameter and blood IgG and IgM analyses, and nucleic acid examination of pharyngeal swab specimens were performed on the patients and their escorts when they were admitted to the hospital.
Third, only the escorts of the patient who passed the above test with negative results were allowed to accompany the patient, and a minimum number of people were allowed to accompany the patient.

If the patient was diagnosed as having suspected COVID-19 in the above examination, they were admitted to the suspected COVID-19 ward for further investigation. If the diagnosis was confirmed, the patient was transferred to the infected area for treatment. Fourth, newly admitted patients were placed in protective isolation in single rooms. After repeated monitoring of body temperature by medical professionals, if there were no abnormalities and none of the symptoms mentioned above were present, then 24 hours later, the patient was given a second pharyngeal swab for nucleic acid examination. If negative, the patient was transferred to the general ward for 2-3 days. Patient indicator information of COVID-19 will be announced in the department medical staffs' WeChat group announcement and updated daily. Fifth, hospitalized patients wore masks at all times, and visitors as well as exchanges with other patients were strictly prohibited. Sixth, the suspected COVID-19 and general wards in the department were managed independently by staff, and the staff were strictly prohibited to change across wards.

They also need to maintain strict protective measures among themselves, such as wearing a mask if two or more people sleep in the same duty room. Seventh, patients going out for checks or eating were assigned a special route, and there was regular professional disinfection. Eighth, routine bronchoscopy was performed before lung surgery, and nucleic acid examination was performed, along with an analysis of the secretions from the lower respiratory tract.
Ninth, after several days (generally 1-2 week) of examination and surgical preparation, lung cancer patients with no evidence of COVID-19 underwent routine operation.
Competing interests: The authors have declared no competing interests.

BIBREF2.title: COVID-19 or Lung Cancer: what should we treat?

BIBREF3.title: Alert to Potential Contagiousness: A Case of Lung Cancer with Asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 Infection

BIBREF4.title: CT imaging and clinical course of asymptomatic cases with COVID-19 pneumonia at admission in Wuhan

FIGREF0.text: . Lucia Bonomi and colleagues presented a patient with metastatic lung cancer died rapidly after infecting COVID-19 2 . Marco Russano and colleagues believed that tumor patients had a higher risk of lethal COVID-19 complications 3 . These seem not good news for COVID-19 patients combined with cancer. Therefore, the dramatic COVID-19 outbreak requires extreme caution on not only the covid-19 misdiagnosed as lung cancer, but also the inclusion of covid-19 in patients with lung cancer. However, the high-resolution CT findings of some COVID-19 patients are dominated by GGO-like changes, and these patients can even have only one localized lesion, with vacuoles, pleural traction, and the invasion of pulmonary capillaries 4 . These observations are highly consistent with the classic CT signs of lung cancer. How to differentiate lung cancer from COVID-19 is a challenge in Wuhan, where the outbreak is currently controlled and the number of early-stage lung cancer and asymptomatic COVID-19 patients is increasing 5 . This adds to the problem of identifying those with asymptomatic COVID-19. Doctors' concerns are twofold: first, patients with COVID-19 are being mistakenly treated for lung cancer, and these individuals could undergo an unnecessary operation. Second, patients with lung cancer with COVID-19 during the perioperative period can experience severe complications or nosocomial infection events.
